title: Bitcoin's Bull Case, Macro, AI & 2026 Predictions | Jordi Visser
transcript: The odds on Bitcoin being an important asset 10 years from now, 20 years from now are extremely high. The reason I'm confident that the market cap of Bitcoin will be much higher and I think that's going to be a big story behind the rally next year. You wrote that Bitcoin is the purest AI trade because its belief emote strengthens as AI speeds up. >> Bitcoin is the only thing that I'm aware of, not Ethereum, not Solana, not any of them because it's the only one that doesn't actually need to worry about the innovation comparison. How close do you think we are to the end of this particular distribution phase? >> I'll make a uh a big statement here. I actually think it's over. The OG's will continue to be selling. They were inspired by an ideology of anarchy of of I don't believe the government is doing the right thing for us. There will be a short squeeze in in Bitcoin at some point over the next few years. >> Well, a few things around strategy. I think one is it was the first time I think I've ever heard Michael Sailor say that he would consider selling Bitcoin. He has an OG advantage here from a business standpoint in the digital capital structure of the future. That's what I believe in. Good morning, afternoon or evening and welcome back to another podcast episode here on Coin Bureau. Uh today we are being joined by Jordi Vissa. He is the head of AI macro Nexus research at 22V research and one of the deepest thinkers out there on a plethora of topics. So Jordi, a very warm welcome to the Coin Bureau. >> Thanks Nick. It's good to be here finally. >> Yeah, finally. Before we dive in, guys, quick few disclaimers. Nothing in this video is financial or investment advice. Please consult the disclaimer in the description for more information and consult your financial adviser before making investment decisions. Now Jordy, as I mentioned in in the intro, you have a breadth of knowledge on numerous topics, and it was hard to kind of narrow down most of these questions I had for you. But given that we are a cryptonative channel, I would love to start on what's going on with Bitcoin right now. And this brings us to your latest piece, which is titled quote, "Handicap in the future, what horses, poker, and macro legends taught me about Bitcoin." And it was really optimistic, especially for now when it seems that the general consensus especially on crypto Twitter is one of a bearish take. And I actually found this quite enlightening. So I actually summarized a few of the points in it on my Twitter. And and these are one, the edge isn't predicting the future. It's spotting when the crowd is wrong on probability. Two, Bitcoin's biggest feature right now isn't tech. It's how few people actually own it. and three, the best riskreward shows up when most people still think the idea is stupid. So, I want to kick over to you now. Do you want to potentially expand on a few of those? Is that a good read of um the thesis? And and what else do you want to add to that? >> Yeah, it is. And I and I let me clarify just one point on it. So, I'm uh I'm a person who thinks far out, but let's just break it down this way. I was trained as a trader. So, I have the ability of talking to anyone on the crypto side and I can tell you, you know, current sentiment on Bitcoin is extremely low. I can I just posted something on X highlighting that in the equity market, we're seeing beta outperform quality. So, think of it as risk outperforming safety. When Bitcoin fell from, you know, 120 down to 80, the equity market was also seeing the same type of move where risk was breaking down relative to safety. What I'm focused on in this piece is I have no doubt in my mind that the odds on Bitcoin being an important asset 10 years from now, 20 years from now are extremely high. That does not connect back to the people I talked to on Wall Street. And when I say Wall Street, what people need to understand is the greatest argument for Bitcoin to me is both the demographic argument, but also the percentage of market cap for Bitcoin relative to the rest of what I would consider the store of value. And what people kind of get into is converting Bitcoin to digital gold. I will write a a Substack at some point soon with a belief I have that Bitcoin a store of value is equity. A store of value is bonds. A store of value is real estate. A store of value is gold. Bitcoin to me is not digital gold. It's a digital store of value, which means it is converted or it should be compared to the entire fiat store value. I think this is an argument that Michael Sailor has too. I believe in it as well. So, the reason I'm confident that the market cap of Bitcoin will be much higher and that it's mispriced right now, and that's what I go through in in this piece, is that 5 to 10 years from now, there will be a rotation out of these fiat assets and into Bitcoin. It sure should have happened at a faster pace, but the reality is to the degree that it did happen is why Bitcoin's market cap has been soaring faster than any of the fiat market cap. So for everyone who's listening, and I'm sure your audience is predominantly crypto-based, I can tell you in my meetings with anyone above the age of 50, the probability that they embrace this story is very, very low. The higher an age you go, the lower it gets. The more money they have, the lower it gets. So if you believe in this transference of wealth over the course of the future, the odds on Bitcoin working or continuing to go higher is very, very high. If you add in the demographics that for every dollar transferred from someone in their 70s to someone in their 30s has a positive edge to it, which is the way again I handicap a horse race. That has a positive tailwind to it. So I'm not getting caught up, Nick, in the day-to-day things. This is my view in the future. And then I'll incorporate kind of the thing I said about risk versus beta or risk versus volatility in the equity market as a timing tool. I think Bitcoin is going to go much much higher and I think it's because there's so many people that doubt it still that control most of the world's money. >> Yeah. You've also in that piece or you've said it numerous times that and this ties into your thinking around AI which you're also very bullish on. You wrote that Bitcoin is the purest AI trade because its belief emote strengthens as AI speeds up which is a pretty bold statement. So can you expand on that a bit more? Yeah, this is something also that I I strongly believe in. We we're leaving we're leaving a capitalist system that took time for innovation to go from idea to public company. So if you just literally go through how long it it would take to come up with an idea. Let's start with an industrial idea. I want to become an oil company. Okay. So what do you have to do if you want to go compete with a large oil company in the world? Well, you have to find oil. You have to borrow billions of dollars to get the equipment to go drill oil. You have to do all of these things and then hope that the price of oil actually goes higher. Think about all of that for every industrial. If you want to be a car company, if you want to be a wrench company, whatever it is, you have to borrow lots of money. You have to have lots of physical locations. You have to go trade the commodity markets. All of these physical things. What happened over the last 18 years was we transitioned into the digital economy. In the digital economy, if you came up with an idea that I want to create a a client relationship manager system, CRM, you didn't need to go do all that stuff. You could actually do it on code. The code was both your employers, but then you use the internet. The internet and the platforms allow you to not have to go buy buildings or go around the world. And these companies like Salesforce.com, like Google, like all of the companies built on code were able to have incredibly high margin businesses. They didn't need to take money out for debt and so that idea became something much quicker and with a much lower cost and that's why those companies dominated. The problem with artificial intelligence is artificial intelligence has made code ubiquitous. Anyone can have it who has a phone and it's free. So now all of a sudden there's competition for all of those companies that worked for the last 17 years. So an idea now is verbal. You can say an idea into an app like cursor or like Devon or like Replet or like any of these things. You can have an application that competes with Salesforce.com within minutes. Maybe not on an enterprise scale but on an individual scale. So this is the democratization of education. It's the democratization of taking ideas and building businesses. You connect it to Stripe. You put it on the internet and all of a sudden you have competition. So there are no moes anymore. The other side is the belief system of Bitcoin. Bitcoin has gone from zero to acceptance. The Bitcoin white paper has become a part of history and a part of something that is up for the Nobel Prize in terms of the way a lot of people think about it. Mark Andre has written about it in that framework. So you have something that is meant to not be disrupted by a moat. It could have competition, but at this point I think it's already won the battle as being the digital store of value. And so when you get to that place in time, AI will disrupt all businesses. It has already disrupted real estate. And the reason it's disrupted real estate is we had COVID. COVID made allowed people to work from home. Well, now around the globe, you don't need physical buildings to go work in. You can create a business very quickly with very few employees. You don't need to borrow money. So we've made real estate in this concept of traveling into cities moot. It's just not there. So AI as it accelerates, as humanoids come in, all businesses, regardless of what they do, even manufacturing businesses, because if humanoids cost $20,000, you're now bringing the margins into physical companies as well. Everything goes from idea to monetization. And Bitcoin is the only thing that I'm aware of, not Ethereum, not Solana, not any of them that doesn't have it's a belief, it's not an innovation. And that becomes the strength. So I believe Bitcoin will be the best performing asset because it's the only one that doesn't actually need to worry about the innovation comparison. >> Very good argument and so it's that concept of in an AI world uh there is no scarcity and Bitcoin is a scarce asset in terms of its supply. So coming back to the arguments around a lot of the big institutional asset allocators out there that you know of because obviously you have a trady background. You still work with these guys. you talk with them regularly and one of them you say is demographic as well in terms of age component but what are their main reasons for still not wanting to allocate to bitcoin I guess to the extent in your piece you say that they still pric in you know bitcoin at a 100 to1 or even worthless while you're closer to 3:1 in terms of the potential upside for bitcoin if you're coming back to the idea of horse racing so why do you think they're mispricing it so much >> two very simple human emotions fear fear and need. So on the on the need side, let's start with the need. If you're wealthy, why do you need Bitcoin? You've already accomplished what you want. If you have quote unquote a billion dollars, $100 million, $50 million, you don't actually need it. And I think again, Michael Sailor has done a great job of arguing that the the countries, the companies, the individuals that need it will eventually get there. I think his business micro strategy when he described when I first really got interested in this connection between tradfi and macro and AI it was based on the premise of what Michael Sailor said which is his business was being disrupted. Who is it being disrupted by? The government in terms of the debasement side. He had a he had a billion dollars of cash sitting on his balance sheet, but the government was now moving rates to zero, which means he wasn't going to receive any interest, which sped up his demise if he just let it sit there in treasuries. On the on the other side, he was being disrupted by AI. And yes, it was AI. It was machine learning has been around since 2007, 2008 in a big way, growing way. But he talked about the fact that he couldn't compete with the Mag 7, that Microsoft was already destroying his business and how would he ever catch up. So he was a zombie. On the flip side, for all the things we mentioned, if you're a pension fund manager who runs a pension fund, you clearly don't have the need at this point because the Mag 7 have been producing returns that are very similar to what's been happening with Bitcoin. So we actually need the growth stocks to start underperforming, which I believe, as I said, is going to happen with AI. And I believe it's going to start happening in 2026, which is the most bullish argument I can make for Bitcoin is that they're going to be searching for need finally. But on on the flip side, you have the fear side. If a pension fund makes an allocation to Bitcoin and it proves out to be a scam, they lose their job. So they don't have the incentive to get involved in it. This is the way the traditional finance world works. If you have money, you don't want to take risk. If you're a billionaire and your kid is running the the family office, the kid's going to be defensive with the money until the patriarch is gone. The matriarch is gone. That's just the way it's going to work. So fear and need are the two emotions that are driving, let's say, the speed of it. And that's why when you get someone like El Salvador, why are they involved in it? Because they have the need. They're not scared of the outcome because they've already lived in it. So Bitcoin is owned primarily by people in that framework. I wrote a paper called the silent IPO which was about the old guard, the OGs that are now selling. Well, they got involved for ideological reasons, but they were wealthy. They weren't poor people. They weren't the people that needed it. They were inspired by an ideology of anarchy of of I don't believe the government is doing the right thing for us. Well, now, unfortunately, they have no need to own it. Not in the size that they do because they're now wealthy or wealthier than they ever were. So I believe there's a churning that's going on around these levels. The government is supporting it. They're trying to get individuals in. ETFs have come. They're allowing individuals to get in. So we're opening up the door. And I think this is the way people should always think about it. There's people that have need. There's people that on the flip side are fearful. And I think that's what's slowing down or being the friction of moving more money faster over. >> Yeah. And you come you made a point there around what's required for these allocators to want to consider investing into Bitcoin or shifting into Bitcoin. And that's the concept of growth stocks underperforming which help which will be helped on by AI. My question is related to that is in that scenario when AI is you know transforming the world all these AI companies the ones that are in the mag 7 that are driving a lot of the stock performance right now they're going to continue performing surely in terms of like growth. Is it potentially a situation where AI companies right now in the in the right now that have been performing so well could take away some of that mind share and indeed momentum investing factors if you think about trading as factors momentum is one of them that these allocators may think actually you know although I know that growth stocks what the traditional growth stocks aren't doing well because AI is a disruptor I could just allocate to one of the best performing asset classes of last year which was AI and a Mag 7. Well, here's the reality with the Mag 7. The S&P 500 this year is up about 16 17% as we speak. Of the MAG 7, five of the seven companies have underperformed the S&P 500. Only Google has really outperformed this year. I believe that that's going to continue. So, in no way, shape, or form do I believe those companies are going to outperform. And the reason I say the S&P 500 is because what people have to think about, yes, the S&P 500 is up a lot this year, but this is with those companies being up. I think many of them are going to be under pressure because they're doing something that they didn't have to do ever. If you go back to my argument of an oil company and what it needed, these mag seven companies are spending an enormous amount of money to compete with the other companies on a commodity that is free. So they're spending t tons of money hoping that they're going to get their revenues in the door. I don't think they're going to get enough revenues in the door to justify the earnings multiple that they have. So I expect that their earnings multiples will compress over time. There will be some like Tesla and things that'll benefit from humanoids that'll probably outperform, but the reality is when you go through the rest of the world, Tesla is very similar to Bitcoin. The majority of people on Trafy don't believe in Tesla. They don't believe in Elon Musk. It's one of my favorite topics in the world. The Substack I wrote two weeks ago was on the credibility of Alon Musk and what he's talking about. If the world goes through what I think it's going to go through so far this year, we had a big AI year, but foreign stocks have outperformed the US. The DAX has outperformed the S&P 500 or Europe has outperformed, especially in in currency terms because the dollar has weakened. while the rest of the world or all the global benchmarks are dependent kind of on the mag 7 and software names to outperform. So I do believe this is uh getting in the weeds a little bit here but I don't think people should underestimate the fact that with AI happening you're actually going to see the underperformance of growth stocks and people are going to be looking for some kind of growth and I think Bitcoin is going to be the place that they migrate to more and more. I fully expect that sovereign wealth funds, pension funds and everything around that around the globe will allocate more and more money towards Bitcoin in uh in the coming year and I think that's going to be a big story behind the rally next year. >> Okay, we'll get on to that in a bit. I just want to pick on one point you made there around and this relates to the whole AI trade itself that these companies that have these massive valuations and multiples the the hyperscalers etc that they could struggle to get the revenue to justify those those valuations. Why why do you think that exactly? >> I think it's almost in my mind it's almost a foregone conclusion and I and I say this from a very simple thing. They're competing with each other. So there's no way that all of them are going to win. They're spending an enormous amount of money. It I'm not saying in any way that they won't get revenues. Uh the people that think there's an AI bubble, I completely disagree with that. But there's a difference between there being a bubble and these stocks becoming more boring companies. meaning they're getting revenue in, but they have to keep spending more money to get better compute to compete with the other players. You've seen that already this year, meaning Open AI is now, you know, they're questioning whether they're going to be around because of the deals they're making and how much money. Well, this is a company that doesn't have the advantage that Google does. Google has a business in search, which is a cash cow. Open AAI needs to borrow their money to actually go through. If Open AI were in trouble, I think all of the multiples of these companies would come down because it would be proof that it's very hard to monetize this. So, no one has proved yet that they're going to be able to monetize it in a big enough way to justify the amount of spending that's going on. In my weekly video that I do where I connect tradfi to AI to crypto, I highlight an interview that Dario Modi did from Anthropic with uh Aaron Ross Sorcin which went through in an honest fashion the difficulty that all these hyperscalers have with predicting the revenue. And if they make a mistake, they're at severe risk. their businesses could go under because they're dependent on the data centers and all of these things that I believe as AI gets better and better. The disruption that will come from these investments they made, these data centers could become worthless over time. They could be stranded assets in 5 years. And if that's the case, the people that made these big bets, when a new innovation comes, Elon Musk is talking about solar satellites. If that process goes faster in all these data centers, if you want to have your stuff in space because it's cheaper to run, you don't have that advantage. There's a whole bunch of things that are going to happen. AI creates a very, very difficult way to predict the future. And that's why I'll continue to say when you're dealing with Bitcoin, you're dealing with, hey, we're only worth $2 trillion and the fiat assets are somewhere between 500 trillion to 800 trillion. I like that ratio in terms of that one side getting bitter bigger and the other one even if it only goes down a h 100red trillion that's still a big move for Bitcoin. >> Yeah, for sure. So speaking about Bitcoin now and you mentioned it earlier um your silent IPO thesis was I would say one of the most widely shared Bitcoin pieces over the whole year and in it you argued that Bitcoin's kind of frustrating sideways action wasn't weakness but a massive healthy distribution of phase from the OGs holders to the institutions in this IPO phase. I guess my first question is how close do you think we are to the end of this particular distribution phase? I'll make a uh a big statement here. I actually think it's over. I think it's kind of been over to some degree since October. And and this is the reason why I'll say it's over. The OG's will continue to be selling, but it comes down to is there more buying power now? When we were going up to all-time highs, what people have to understand is the selling was happening during that entire article. This wasn't something that I wrote. I was hearing about it. Mike Novogratz was talking about it openly from Galaxy in the earnings reports. this had been going on during the summertime. So when I see anything that has that much upward buying pressure, which again I view uh I view this as being kind of the important buyers of the world, let's break them down so that people can get kind of my deep feelings on the way this is working. There's three buyers that I care about. One of them, let's just put them in as the most important buyer, which are countries like El Salvador. They're very tiny. Meaning, if a kid in Brazil becomes an entrepreneur and they don't trust their government and they want to put money into Bitcoin after they've done some stable coin transactions, selling a new app that they developed using AI to an American or to an Aussie or to a European and they collect $10 and they have those $10 and they don't want to keep it in Brazilian realis. So what they do is they put seven of it into stable coins, dollar back stable coins to protect against the depreciation, but then they want to have money working for them and they put a certain amount of money into Bitcoin. This is kind of what Tether does with their gold holdings, their Bitcoin holdings and the excess return. So I want everyone to just think about that is a small portion of the pie dollar-wise because you don't have Brazilians having much money. The second point is the institutional side, the ETF buyers. Let's put them in as the wealthy individuals around the globe including pension funds, sovereign wealth funds and the people in the western world. Most of the M2 of the world is effectively in China, the US and Europe. Whether people understand this, that is probably 75% of global money supply and wealth is in those three countries. So we kind of depend on those three countries to be the drivers of it. The OGs are also in those countries as well. So you have the OGs selling to other people inside that country that again in the US when I talk to people a lot of the Americans that are buying it they're electricians there are plumbers they're people that have already been forced out of the system those buyers are there they're offsetting the OG side and I think they're growing every day and more importantly the younger demographic is offsetting them so when you take the one buyers which are the poorer people of the world which I think are structurally bullish and will always invest in it because they're hiding from their government then you have the wealthy people which are doing it which is great. You still have you know that part going on but then you get into a third component which to me I think is the reason why which is retail traders. Retail traders are a different breed. Retail traders are people that have already decided in the modern world and these are younger people below the age of 50 for sure. I would say mostly below the age of 40. I do a regular weekly podcast with Anthony Pompiano and I've gotten to meet a lot of these traders. Crypto traders are real traders. They remind me of myself as a young person getting into the business at Morgan Stanley. Well, they're the ones that drove it from 120 from probably from 100 to 126 and then from 126 back to 80 because a lot of the names that they were trading in the AI space, the Palunteers, the Nvidas, those names got bludgeoned during October and November. I think that buying power is now back to clean. It's enormous. whenever that buying power is there and they only play from the long side when it starts to get going. We just need to see some moving averages tick out. I believe when Bitcoin gets back up on the year, I'll say three daily closes above 92,000 which is about where it closed last year. I think the retail crowd will be back in pushing this thing. We'll have the option volume going in and I think at that point we'll get back to the all-time highs and I think the OGs have reduced. I'll add one other seller that's been critical for the IPO part which people have to think about as well and that's the Bitcoin miners. And I think the Bitcoin miners have been reduced going forward as a seller because of AI because their businesses are now starting to get a revenue stream which means they don't have to sell as much as they did in the past. And that's because their electricity is becoming extremely valuable. Always remember and if you saw Lon Mus speak last week he talked about the fact that Bitcoin is pure energy. If electricity prices are going higher, then the Bitcoin miners don't need to be involved as much on the sell side in terms of hedging their business because their electricity is worth a lot of money. Their compute power is worth a lot of money. So, I believe the miners are be are going to become less of let's say call option sellers, which is this phantom supply that people don't see that often. It's to hedge their revenue and the risk they have if the price drops. I don't think they're going to need to sell as much as electricity prices go up. So that's a long-winded answer for you, Nick, but I got a lot out there. >> There's so many threads I want to pull on there. Wow. Okay. So, so you say so you think in in terms of what could get Bitcoin, it's momentum, right? So momentum in terms of these traders, you say it's retail traders who when they see momentum coming in, they see Bitcoin holding, you know, above support levels. Okay? And they're pure traders, meaning they don't they're not Bitcoin holders for the long term. Let's just we know that a lot of them are, but let's just assume they're not. So I wrote a piece believing that Bitcoin will definitely be 10 20 30 times higher than it is today in the future. The question for me is whether that's a 20-year story, a 30-year story, a 15ear story, 10. I don't really care. And that's the way I allocate my money from in a long-term investment theme is I want to have less money in the fiat assets. The energy that matters is retail has learned a lesson that fiat people don't think about. Fiat people are always looking for the bare side. The reason there's an AI bubble article every single day is because they realized how hard it was to make that money climbing the wall of worry for the last 40 years. So if you're a 60-year-old and you've made tons of money and you know the government is basically bailing out the system every time COVID happens or any SVB happens, you believe the system's rigged and it's going to crash. On the other side, you have retail which is younger. They're hungry and they're like, "No, this is like going to Vegas and the odds are you're going to make money 85% of the time. So, I just want to play from the long side." And every now and then, if the market's not working, if you read my piece, what my father taught me is, hey, if this is a race where you can't find any value, sit it out. That's what retail good retail traders do. If they see the bull market's not working, they just reduce their bets and they try to pick the bottom of Bitcoin until it goes. But once they feel comfortable and it's working and they feel that now, like blackjack, hey, I'm a card counter and I know now I should be tripling my bets, they will triple their bets. They will leverage in. They will get bigger and bigger because that is the way you make money in a pure way in this in a rigged market, which I believe it is. You're playing it like blackjack. You make your bets three times as more when the technicals are lining up and that fever is going. So what retail does is they actually set up the next trend. They'll get out of that stuff at some point. But when you're playing the game and you believe that over the course of the next three years, like like salmon going, you want to go with the river. You don't want to go against it. Bitcoin's going to be a million in 10 years. I want to find the points where the moving averages start to tick higher and I want to jump in during that because I know I could miss a 100,000 to 300,000 if I'm worried about being a bare market when these things are not going to last that long. That is the thing that I think retail traders do. They are the energy in there to fuel this. And I think they're going to fuel the next one along with the sovereign funds, along with less selling from the things I go. They're the ones that are going to turn this back above a 100 and then it'll start feeding on itself. >> Fascinating. And is it um do you think that's the the retail traders just buying spot? It's a strategy that people use in that manner. I think their comfort for leverage is high. So although they'll trade spot, I think when they really get bullish, they go buy call options.
